idea.title: Create with math
idea.body: A Penrose tiling is an example of an aperiodic tiling: a covering of the plane by non-overlapping shapes that never repeats in a regular cycle. Despite lacking translational symmetry, these tilings can still exhibit reflection symmetry and high-order rotational symmetry. Named after mathematician and physicist Roger Penrose, they show how local rules generate global order without periodic patterns. This page lets you explore that idea interactively: adjust symmetry, phase, scale, noise and color to see how small rule changes reshape the whole structure.

controls.label: Symmetry
controls.description: Number of rotational axes. Sets the families of guiding lines and the types of tiles available. Higher values produce richer combinations.

controls.label: Pattern
controls.description: Phase offset of the pattern. Slides line families against each other to change tile arrangements without altering symmetry.

controls.label: Rotate
controls.description: Rotates the scene (degrees). Spins the view around the center without changing the underlying rules.

controls.label: Radius
controls.description: Construction radius in grid steps. Larger radius generates a wider area and more tiles in view.

controls.label: Zoom
controls.description: Visual scale of the tiling. Enlarges or reduces tile size on screen at a fixed construction radius.

controls.label: Pan
controls.description: Horizontal camera shift. Moves the viewport left/right without regenerating the pattern.

controls.label: Disorder
controls.description: Amount of random deviation in line placement. Low values keep strict geometry; higher values add organic variation.

options.description: Fills tiles using the current palette.
Shows the constructive line grid the tiles derive from.

controls.label: Color (N°)
controls.description: Base hue in degrees on the color wheel (0–360). Shifts the overall palette; specific tile types can be manually overridden if custom coloring is enabled.
